normalised: **Quora Post: Rental Agreements - What is the Deal? (Real Estate and Property)**

unnormalised: Okay, so you're moving to Mumbai, Bangalore, or maybe even back to your native Patna after years abroad? Finding a place is just the first hurdle. The REAL deal is the rental agreement. Seriously, don't just skim it and sign like you're agreeing to receive daily biryani. Read. Every. Line.
normalised: Okay, so you are moving to Mumbai, Bangalore, or maybe even back to your native Patna after years abroad? Finding a place is just the first hurdle. The real deal is the rental agreement. Seriously, don't just skim it and sign like you are agreeing to receive daily biryani. Read. Every. Line.

unnormalised: First things first, get it in writing! Verbal promises in India are worth less than a broken samosa. A proper agreement outlines the rent (say, Rs. 15,000/month), the deposit (usually like, 2-3 months rent, so Rs. 30,000-45,000), and the notice period (typically 1-2 months).
normalised: First things first, get it in writing! Verbal promises in India are worth less than a broken samosa. A proper agreement outlines the rent (say, rupee fifteen thousand per month), the deposit (usually like, two to three months rent, so rupee thirty thousand to forty five thousand), and the notice period (typically one to two months).

unnormalised: Make sure it specifies who pays for what. Does the rent include society maintenance? What about those pesky electricity bills that always seem to spike around Diwali? Spell it out!
normalised: Make sure it specifies who pays for what. Does the rent include society maintenance? What about those pesky electricity bills that always seem to spike around Diwali? Spell it out!

unnormalised: Landlord trying to sneak in clauses about surprise inspections? Question it! You have a right to privacy.
normalised: Landlord trying to sneak in clauses about surprise inspections? Question it! You have a right to privacy.

unnormalised: And what about repairs? Who's responsible if the roof leaks during the monsoon or if the geyser konks out? Mention it in the agreement.
normalised: And what about repairs? Who is responsible if the roof leaks during the monsoon or if the geyser konks out? Mention it in the agreement.

unnormalised: I know this sounds like a lecture, but trust me, a clear rental agreement can save you a HUGE headache later. Think of it as insurance against future "chai pe charcha" arguments with your landlord over who owes what. Don't be like Raju who forgot and ended up having to paint the entire apartment on his own before Onam! Learn from his mistakes!
